author: oakenbucket
body:
Also in October, the deal with MSFT was [announced](https://news.microsoft.com/2020/10/08/gamestop-announces-multiyear-strategic-partnership-with-microsoft/).

They’re shifting all their business operations to the Microsoft 365 stack, including CRM Dynamics.  They’ll be setup for better data driven decisions and collaboration.  It also equips all staff with Surface devices on the sales floor.  Maybe something like the Apple store where there’s not really a register anymore.  Just checkout with the employee anywhere.

This deal also includes a GME cut of all digital sales from Xboxes sold from GME for the life of the console.  That’s some nice extra revenue for essentially little effort.  And this happened in October!  I’m wondering if we’ll see how much they made from that deal with nextgen console sales in their next quarterly.

author: Footsteps_10
body:
Does Palantir actually have a much better product than its competitors? With two competitors listed in the report, SBC booming 1000% in one year, SGA equaling Sales and Marketing (which is really odd) roughly, it just seems like there is so much young investor hype.

Can anyone explain to me how SAP/CRM couldn't pivot into this business?

As Cuban and other savy investors always trash, the TAM is always larger than perceived. Growth in the TAM is always smaller than realized and they are losing money YoY.

I truly feel without Reddit there would be much less hype surrounding the investment. I am going to stay away until this company is actually profitable. If I had an infinite portfolio, I would buy some shares, but we all live in a finite society.

author: Bigrigric
body:
Salesforce is an expensive, tired product. Nobody who uses it loves it. They are an incumbent ripe for displacement as soon as somebody figures out how to eliminate all the non-revenue generating, redundant, wasted, time we all spend in salesforce.

Salesforce sells mgmt on “if it’s not in salesforce, it didn’t happen”

In practice this looks like an entire sales team spending a day daily/monthly/quarterly entering in fake “no answer - vm left” calls in order to bring their activities up. Most people don’t feel like going through  5-10 clicks for every call that the client didn’t pick up the phone.

I could not think if a worse way for you’re sales team to spend their time.

author: 9tacos
body:
They basically are the original SaaS cloud providers.  They really created the business model with their universally extensible schema design on Oracle.  Layered on top of their base CRM, their model based application development environment is very customizable, proprietary and ensures complete vendor lock-in.  Once enterprises are on boarded they are pretty much a guaranteed revenue stream for a long time.  Switching costs are huge. They have a great ecosystem, community and actively make good strategic acquisitions.  

It’s a very good business with a solid moat.

author: MarchHill
body: CRM is one of those companies that is here to stay. I don't people understand just how HUGE the Salesforce ecosystem is. Any company with a sales team larger than a dozen people, there's a 90% chance you're using a CRM, and a 90% chance that the CRM is Salesforce. More and more companies that use a database like MS Access or a free CRM will eventually move to Salesforce. I've been an end user for over a decade and was certified as an Admin for a couple years too. There's so many ways for them to generate revenue. I'd put them in the same tier as companies like NVIDIA, Intel, ServiceNow as companies that probably will not stop growing. They may not grow as fast as growth stocks, but they'll not stop growing.

author: TheAlbinoShadow
body:
Ah found it, and secured early access... here's further projection summary:

> **Bear Case**: Ecommerce growth, accelerated by COVID-19, stops at 27.5% share, footprint is reduced to 2,000 stores in US/Canada, SG&A improvements are completed, the console cycle decays, and GameStop does not innovate as consumers shift overwhelmingly to digital

> **Base Case**: Shift to ecommerce continues at a reduced rate to 37.5% by 2025, new digital partnerships are struck, margins improve as new product segments are added, and digital revenue such as advertising and e-sports leverage the CRM value of an enhanced PowerUp program

> **Bull Case**: Ryan Cohen accelerates digital transformation by boosting ecommerce contribution to 45% via improved CX, aggressively pursues business partnerships, and leverages the full potential of 20M+ active PowerUp members across multiple digital businesses and channels

author: tdnewmas
body:
NIO -- Investor. I plan to drive my Kia into the ground and then buy an EV. Which EV? Either a Tesla or NIO. I doubt NIO cars will be available any time soon in the US, but based on how many miles a drive each year, I won't be on the market for another 10 years.

TTD -- Investor. I don't work in advertising, but I love everything about The Trade Desk. I've looked at their Careers page, but I don't want to spend 3+ hours a day commuting to their SF office from my house. They could pay me double and I still wouldn't take it. I value being able to walk my dog and get errands done during my lunch break.

CRM -- I've been using Salesforce at various jobs for well over a decade now. But as a $200 billion company, I would only invest in them if I'm looking for a safe stock to buy, but I'm at the phase in my life where I want to buy risky stocks that have a chance to 5-10x in the next decade.

SQ -- I love the CashApp, but I'm not invested in them

ETSY -- I've bought many a Christmas and birthday gift from Etsy, but I've never been invested in the company

author: SnooRabbits4383
body:
No matter what happens with COVID-19 in 2021, cloud spending isn't expected to slow. That makes cloud-based customer relationship management (CRM) software provider **salesforce.com** ([NYSE:CRM](https://www.fool.com/quote/nyse/salesforcecom-inc/crm/)) a solid bet to outperform with Biden in the White House.

In simple terms, CRM software helps businesses track customer information, log service issues, and manage their marketing campaigns. Although retail is the most logical beneficiary of CRM solutions, it's by no means the end-all. Manufacturing, healthcare, information technology, and service industries all benefit from real-time customer data to better serve their existing clients and make add-on sales.

In terms of CRM software, [salesforce is the kingpin](https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/12/28/got-1000-3-stocks-to-buy-to-start-2021-with-a-bang/). **Gartner** estimated that it controlled 18.3% of the global CRM market at the end of 2019. That's more than double its next-closest competitor. With the addition of **Slack Technologies**, which salesforce has [agreed to acquire for $27.7 billion in cash and stock](https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/12/01/salesforce-building-the-operating-system-for-the-f/), salesforce will have another way to cross-sell its products on a rapidly growing business-based platform.

Considering that most [software-as-a-service (SaaS) stocks](https://www.fool.com/investing/stock-market/market-sectors/information-technology/saas-stocks/) are valued at 20 or more times sales, salesforce looks like an absolute bargain at less than 10 times fiscal 2021 sales.

Technical analysis: Head and shoulders pattern, bullish signal

Position: 230C March 19th expiry

author: CoyoteClem
body: Hi.  Wow.  You've put a tremendous amount of work into all of this, and it's incredible of you to share.  I take a similar approach.  I use Morningstar reports (a popular analysts which you can access for free on Charles Schwab) to see if a business is good and favorably valued.  Morningstar focuses on qualitative analysis and also makes judgements about whether a business has a moat (no moat, narrow moat, wide moat).  So, my strategy is I look on Morningstar to see which companies have a wide moat.  Then I take notice on how a wider array of analysts including Morningstar values the current stock price.  All of this gives me some assurance that the company is long lasting and defensible, and it's a fair price.  Then I see which of these Wide Moat stocks are also in Ark Invest funds.  This tells me if the stock is also offensive.  I figure why not buy a business that Morningstar thinks is defensive and what Ark Invest thinks is offensive (growth).  There's actually a lot of companies that fall in this category.  They've included Google, Salesforce, Amazon, Adobe, Intuit, Ansyss, Roche, Novartis, Charles Schwab, Mercado Libre, Caterpillar, and probably a few others that I can't recall at the moment.  My last filter is that I do not buy companies that have a high debt to equity ratio.  I'm concerned about a future looming big debt crisis.  Anyways, I hope that helps you as well.

author: CcpPlzBlowme
body:
the potential news is a joint venture with Apple and Hyundai to make the Apple smart car using canoos existing technology, Hyundai for manufacturing and Apple for brand and whatever else Apple brings to the table. 

if it drops at open to like $18 then you could try some calls, but if it doesn't keep climbing you'll lose money on those calls.  I saw today that one analyst said its undervalued and he put an 80% increase on the stock.  That would put it at around $28-35ish value.  Safer to buy shares at this point.  An article came out saying Apple made them a buyout offer which they declined, and the company is also not commenting.  Obviously Apple needs an WV company in order to produce their vehicle and they already said it's with Hyundai and rumors of cannoo coming in for their tech is rampant. 

The price will either drop at open and climb up throughout the day on all the people buying the news, or it will open high and keep climbing, and if that's the case the calls will be super expensive due to the volitility and hard to make a profit on unless we see 2-3 days straight of large price increase. 

Smart play, like I said, would be to buy shares and hold.  You can sell them at some point and wait for the stock to flatten out and dip and stay stagnent for a day or two, at which point then you can buy long calls. 

go check out the cannoo website, from what I remember off the top of my head they don't plan on producing their vehicle commercially for a year or so, so worst case scenario you hold the shares if they dip, until they are at a point you want to sell them. 

If you want to buy some calls tomorrow you should look into buying Salesforce or bigcommerce which are both low volitility.  You can buy some bigcommerce April calls and hope for good earnings release, also with salesforce you could buy some June $250-280 calls and hope their earnings are good.  the saleforce calls are like 40% volitility right now, so you won't lose a bunch of instant value on the calls since that's such a low volitility, and come earnings that amount will probably increase leading up to the announcement.

author: italiansomali
body:
Hey thanks for your reply!

SAP and CRM could pivot into this business.

However, I believe that it would be very difficult for those companies to compete against PLTR in the government sector given that PLTR already has 17 years of accumulated experience and their software is already used across several agencies in the government which generates network effects.

In the commercial sector, I believe that competition could be much more intense as the companies you mention have more reach than PLTR. Nevertheless, it is important to consider that PLTR is already working with some of the leading firms in the financial services, airline, oil production, and healthcare industries, and if they are able to broaden their reach by partnering with these customers (as they did with Airbus) it could widen their moat significantly.

In evaluating their negative profits, it is important to take into account their customer acquisition strategy and how their margins evolve as the platform's scale within the customer's operations.

author: iBifteki
body:
I just read your edit, which was about to be my point.

To be honest, I've lost track of all their subsidiaries at this point. It's not only Tableau, but Heroku as well (PaaS for applications).

Generally, I've been seeing their little cloud logo everywhere, and their key growth metrics the past 4 years are extremely impressive.

Sustaining growth 20% YoY when you you reach double digit billion revenue is not an easy feat, but they've been continuously smashing it.

The whole point of the Slack acquisition is to leverage the whole remote collab wave, along with all the other tools (Tableau, Slack, Heroku, Einstein, 360, Salesforce Core etc.) for a total platform-Salesforce-ecosystem experience in which upselling businesses becomes a breeze.

This drop is without a sheer of a doubt an overreaction, about a company that has unbelievable guidance and a great track record for making shit happen. This dip will be bought back into mid $200s by the next couple of months the latest, feel free to add a RemindMe below this post and roast me if not.

author: Apprehensive-Cap3622
body: I think the biggest failure is to believe that Palantir mostly operates just with Goverments or Army. I don‘t work on it, but I’m employed at one of worlds biggest consumer goods companies, we work on SAP and switched all Sales matters to Salesforce last year because of their cloud based system (Real-time Data) we also got a new Online Shop for hundreds of brands. View months ago we added Palantir Sofware to bring together all data from SAP, Salesforce & Onlineshop and get finished Analyses of all Sales & Supply Chain matters. Palantir runs behind the online shop an give you every Data and Analyses of Customer behavior. So you can build out Offers and everything you want on your Onlineshop out of its analyses. You also can track the whole logistic with it... So believe me if one of worlds biggest retail companies implement Palantir to run their Data and Analyses, we want be the only one! And if there would be a better software to bring together Data from different Systems we wouldn’t have bought it. By the way Accenture as Worlds leading Business Consultant Company is driving Digital Transformation at the most of the Fortune 500 companies & Governments and if they recommend this software there is a reason... and as I sayed before, there are a lot of Big Groups already using it, you just don‘t read it on the newspaper... And there’s also a reason why all government‘s use it for the vaccine distribution from Europe to USA... why would the  EU Use it if it‘s just bound to US Government? See it from another perspective, Government Contract run long, so they have secured Sales and adding much more with the sales the most people think they don‘t do... wait for the Earnings Call and you will see! 🚀
